sub_title: Senior Architect, Overall Infra EXE:5000 (High-NA EUV) at ASML (FA Scanner FC-057)
summary:
Collaborative and communicative personality, taking early initiatives to establish informal networks as a basis for long-term cooperation for strategy development, system architecting and implementation. Very long industrial R&D experience base in an international setting (Sweden (2005 - 2014), Germany (2014-2016) and the Netherlands (Philips Nat.Lab.: 2001-2005, ASML: 2018 - now) with a focus on thermal design & thermal analysis of very complex industrial equipment. Driven by application of a systems architecture perspective on design (and design process) and engineering for the development of future complex (and possibly fundamentally different) products and/or processes.

Full CV at: http://www.kranenborg.org/jurjen-cv

education.field_of_study: Fluid dynamics + heat and mass transfer in an oceanographic setting

Senior Architect, Overall Infra EXE:5000 (High-NA EUV) at ASML (FA Scanner FC-057)

projects.title: [Semi-professional]: "SerialPower"​ True two-wire power+data network
projects.description:
The microcontroller-based  "SerialPower" Network combines power delivery and
bi-directional communications between processes on intelligent nodes
using just two simple, interchangeable (non-polarized) wires.

This network is based on two - independent - concepts:
- Networking hardware for linking microcontroller-based nodes transmitting power and data over two lines
- Microcontroller network software that implements communicating processes on a multi-drop network

A master node provides for power as well as "timeslots" during which processes on nodes can exchange messages with each other using a standard format. The slave nodes are powered from the network and only need a backup capacitor. Both master and slave nodes may be implemented using any available low-end micorcontroller type (Picaxe or other) since the memory footprint of the SerialNetwork protocol stack is extremely small.

The project name links to the project website

contributors.headline: Senior Architect, Overall Infra EXE:5000 (High-NA EUV) at ASML (FA Scanner FC-057)

projects.title: [Semi-professional]: Near-Space Satellite: PongSat-18X
projects.description:
The PongSat-18X is an home-made microcontroller-based satellite that fits inside a pingpong ball and was flown to the near-space area (about 30 kms high) free of charge by JP Aerospace and was retrieved successfully with an extensive measurement dataset. 

Our project goals were:
- To develop a microcontroller-based pongsat that functions properly through the whole flight (this implies that very low temperatures (-70 Degr. C or less) may be encountered),
- To do a large number of measurements (not just temperature) very regularly and thus learn about the atmosphere.
- To test a number of sensors for their appliccability
- To run the project like a real space project, i.e. build and test prototypes thoroughly and under "harsh conditions", thorough preparation etc.

The project title links to the full project blog that presents the exciting flight results and the development challenges.

profile_positions.title: Senior Architect, Overall Infra EXE:5000 (High-NA EUV) at ASML (FA Scanner FC-057)

profile_positions.description:
Group: Thermal Architecture DUV (Deep Ultra-Violet) Semiconductor Lithography
Dept.: MC DE SCN D
profile_positions.title: Project Lead LITES

profile_positions.description: Responsible for course development, student supervising and applied research in the fields of Embedded Systems (microcontroller applications), Mechatronics, Transport physics and Materials Science.
profile_positions.title: Lecturer Engineering

profile_positions.description:
Responsible for thermal R&D and its integration in the system architecture as member of the Global Architecture Team for product group Medium and Large Power Transformers (PPTR). Concretely this implied the following roles/responsibilities:

- Responsibility for ABB-internal design reviews on new  strategically important transformer designs, failure cases and external (customer) design review support, using CFD, thermal network models and analytical modeling. 
- Project leadership “Transformer Cooling” . Main project activity in 2016 concerned re-architecting thermal design software as part of major overhaul of transformer software design system (guarding architecture requirements for physical,  technical and user domain views in this process).
- Coordinator & contact person of “Cooling Team” (2010-2016): Competence team of 6 people from Corporate Research and Product Group Transformers that works on all aspects of transformer thermal design, model development, implementation, verification and designer support, including coordination of Product Group and CRC strategies through strategic roadmap development.
- R&D to Product Group technology transfer: Introduction of advanced CFD transformer simulations for hot spot determination for use in order design as part of the standard design process in the factories (designer training, service implementation & model delivery).
- Representation of ABB in international standardization workgroup (CIGRE WG A2.38, I was task force leader CFD simulation technologies), 2010 - 2016.
- Project Assessor for project reviews (14 times in total, ABB Gate Model applied to decision process for project follow-up).
- Customer contacts: support with factory audits & promotion of upgrade of design review process for power transformers for increased thermal reliability by design (e.g. Doble Seminar, Dubai 2015, Cordoba Factory Audit EDF customer, 2011).
- Reviewer, IEEE Transactions on Power Systems / Power Delivery (2012-2016)
profile_positions.title: Senior Principal Engineer
Principal Scientist (Thermal Management) & Power Transformer Global Architecture Team member

profile_positions.description: - Team Leader, focusing on the implementation of a new PPTR-funded group of experienced research specialists (5 people) for better utilizing R&D competences in the transformer area and knowledge transfer between Corporate Research and the PPTR (Power Transformers) Division.
